Posts.Content: Hi Dantsa, you just have to come to terms with the fact that on chemo some days you can do stuff and some days you can't. Let your body dictate when go rest and just go with it. I was always a 'doer' but had to retrain myself to be a 'sitter'. It's not for ever so don't worry. I'm 3 months post chemo and 6 weeks post radiotherapy and am about 75% back to normal. I do find though that I don't feel the need to run round like a blue arsed fly like I did before. I'm much more laid back about life. Life now is precious and to be enjoyed!
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy side effects

Posts.Content: I am on Herceptin no7 and still don't know what is caused by the Herceptin and what is a hangover from the chemo and radiotherapy. I had my last radio 3 weeks ago and still feel really low in energy and go dizzy when I stand up.  Is this the radio or is it the Herceptin? Not a clue! Only side effect I know is definitely the Hetceptin is the drippy nose.
Posts.Title: Herceptin Injection

Posts.Content: Lynn, bad news about your seroma, I feel your pain! Mine shrunk during the radiotherapy and I'm left with a hard lump of scar tissue about the size of a walnut. It's a bit of a nuisance but nothing compared to the seroma. I'm having physio this week so hopeful that the scar tissue can be reduced a bit but if it's permanent I guess it's not the end of the world.
Posts.Title: Herceptin Injection

Posts.Content: Thanks Lynn, the trouble is it's not scar tissue on my surgery scars, it's deep inside, like having a walnut held tightly right in my armpit, pressing on my ribs. It's the remnants of the seroma I'm pretty sure. I'm seeing a physio tomorrow so hopefully see if they can manipulate it in some way.
Posts.Title: Herceptin Injection

Posts.Content: Tracy, The doxataxel truly  the work of the devil!!! I am 4 months post chemo and my fingernails have just started falling off. Most of my toes are numb and my big toenails hurt so guess they might be due to go! I am feeling soooooo much better lately and tried to go through Christmas as if I were 'normal' whatever that is now. Big mistake, I had a houseful on Christmas Day and again on Boxing Day and today I'm doing a Caribbean party for my friends birthday. I'm smiling through it all but inside I'm thinking 'whatever possessed me to think I could do all this???'  if you are still having radiotherapy then you can expect to feel tired for a while to come yet but it will get better. If you can stay off work for a few more weeks you should. You shouldn't feel guilty, it's necessary for your body to recover properly, I realise that now when I tried to be mother Christmas and struggled.
Posts.Title: Side effects of fec-t on feet and body

Posts.Content: This is the one time in your life when you need to be a bit selfish. Don't even think about work, your health is more important and you need to see the treatment through whatever it brings so that you can be there in the future for your children.
Posts.Title: First chemo was on 17th August

Posts.Content: For my surgery I was told that I could keep my shellac on as long as my toes were 'au naturel'. They just need to be able to check your sats and check for colour of nails.
Posts.Title: Acrylic nails

Posts.Content: I recently had surgery to resolve my 5 month long  seroma (aka The Alien as it looked just like the one in the film trying to burst out of John Hurt). Unfortunately the surgery didn't work and I now have Alien 2. Had 400ml drained from it this week and now have been given a compression bra which looks and feels like a straight jacket! However that aside I am much more concerned that I also seem to have now got some cording. Just one really thick one going from axillary down my inner arm. BN says to massage it and stretch and at some stage it will pop and be ok. Anyone else had cording and any recommendations to cure it or at least make it a bit less painful?
Posts.Title: How do I get rid of cording?

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for all your advice about the cording. I have been stretching and massaging like mad so hopefully it will crack soon!
Posts.Title: How do I get rid of cording?

Posts.Content: Well after having my last chemo two weeks ago (FEC-T) I rang the bell and celebrated. I should definitely have delayed the celebrations as by day 4 following the last Taxotere I was in hospital yet again with a high temperature. 3 days later my neutrophils dropped to 0.1 and stubbornly stayed there for 4 days before slowly starting to rise. I was finally allowed home after 11 days in hospital when my neuts got to 1.2. Feel as weak as a kitten, lost 5lb in weight while in hospital (quite pleased about that bit) but hopefully out the other end now. I've got my seroma surgery next week so have to spend this week trying to build up my strength. Hopefully it won't be delayed as I really want to push on with everything and get to the radiotherapy stage.
Posts.Title: Going out with a bang

Posts.Content: I've been trying to stretch and massage for a few days. Strange that I didn't get cording after the WLE or the axillary clearance, just after the seroma surgery. I see my BNs twice a week so if it doesn't improve I hope they will maybe organise some physio.  As for the seroma I don't feel very optimistic as the surgery was supposed to cure it and it hasn't. My surgeon doesn't have a plan for it so I suppose I'll just have to hope it eventually dries up.
Posts.Title: How do I get rid of cording?

Posts.Content: After carefully applying mascara to about 3 remaining eyelashes for the last few months I have now discovered a whole new set growing!!!!! They are only about 2mm long but they are all there!!! The hair on my head is also now snout 1cm long, a few bare patches here and there and I must admit I look a bit like a teddy bear but it's progress. Woohoo!!!
Posts.Title: New eyelashes- woohoo!

Posts.Content: My last chemo was 22 Aug. My hair started growing after FEC and during T but my eyelashes didn't fall out until near the end of the T. Had a dream last night that I had a full head of hair, gutted when I woke up and still had the worn out teddy bear look. However the new eyelashes are really cheering me up so I'm hopeful the hair will start catching up soon. Can't wait to dye it but I know I have to be patient.
Posts.Title: New eyelashes- woohoo!

Posts.Content: Hi wsasahw, it's not nice being bald that's for sure. I handled it by thinking 'well if people are going to look at me let's give them something worth looking at!'. I bought loads of scarves and always matched them to my outfit, using sparkly hijab caps underneath to add a bit of glamour. I also used any glitzy elasticated bracelets I had to wrap round the dangly bit of scarf. I got far more complements on my headgear than I ever did for my hair! Don't get me wrong, I still scare the life out of myself when I look in the bathroom mirror in the morning. I'm a redhead so now that my hair is starting to grow I look like a well worn teddy bear, not ready for public viewing for a few more months yet. I have 3 wigs that I alternate and tend to wear them rather than the scarves now that my treatment has finished and also now the weather is colder (wigs were too hot in the summer) Have you got access to a Headstrong course near you? This was very helpful as they show you different ways to tie scarves and also advise on wigs. Don't be afraid to have a good cry but then get that headgear on and put on a fantastic show for your public!! You can do it!
Posts.Title: Braved the Shave

Posts.Content: Your experiences seem to mirror mine almost. I have my last T in 2 weeks and having been in hospital 3 out of the 5 previous cycles (2 of them for the T) and 3 other visits to A&E for high temp where I wasn't admitted I'm resigning myself to one more hospital stay for the last T. No big deal, just go through the motions. The whole chemo experience has been intense but it's all doable and we come out the other end hopefully cancer free.
Posts.Title: Last chemo today, what a journey!!

Posts.Content: Sorry to hear you still have your seroma. After having mine for 7 months last year then having the unsuccessful decortifcation surgery on it I thought I was stuck with mine forever. Thank goodness the radiotherapy made mine shrink. i still have a small amount of fluid but its negligible in comparisson. Hope yours eventually goes. I think leaving it is definitely the best solution as all the faffing about with mine last year (draining 37 times!) made it worse i'm sure.
Posts.Title: Seroma update

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969, I'm half way through FEC-T, will start the T tomorrow. On day 1 of chemo you will have three drugs F- Fluorouacil E- Epiribicin C-Cyclophosphamide Three weeks later you have exactly the same, then again three weeks later then move to the Taxotere  for three cycles. They usually give me about 8 tablets to take before starting which are a mix of anti-sickness drugs. You also get a huge bagful of drugs to take home. It's a bit confusing at first but when I got them I wrote on each box exactly how many to take and when to take them. You will probably also get Filgrastim injections to do at home. Bit scary injecting yourself the first time but it be honest you can't even feel it! The E bit makes your wee pink so don't worry, it's normal. As for side effects everyone is different. I felt slightly queasy for the first week but it didn't stop me eating, just ate my meals but no snacks or alcohol which isn't a bad thing. I did have other issues but won't bore you with the details, just remember everyone us different and you may sail through with nothing. All of it is manageable! Tiredness is a given I think and does get worse each cycle. You can be vulnerable to infection so make sure you take your temp twice a day and call triage if it goes over 37.5. You do have to take this very seriously. I got a good telling off from my oncologist for suggesting I was wasting NHS resources by going to A&E so often. The one time you might ignore the temp is the one time you can end up with sepsis ( don't want to scare you but this is a legitimate scare point) You've got to be in it to win it so the sooner you start the sooner it will be over and you can get on with your life. Good luck.
Posts.Title: FEC-T chemo.

Posts.Content: I just posted about underwire bras then saw your post. I have managed to modify my underwire bras by snipping the top of the channel and taking the wires out. However I also have a lot of post surgery bras including the vest type and also three compression bras that I had to wear to keep my seroma at bay. Does anyone know of a charity that would take these as they are almost new and it's a shame to waste them. Alternatively if anyone on here is a 38DD or 40C I'm happy to donate them.
Posts.Title: Got bras you aren't wearing any more?

Posts.Content: Hi Ronstar, as pointed out I was a member of the seroma sisters but fortunately after 7 months, 37 drainings and seroma surgery(failed) it was the radiotherapy that finally sorted mine out. I still have some fluid there but it's tolerable and there's no way I'd have it drained again. My advice would be to try to resist having it drained unless it's really causing you issues.
Posts.Title: Firm swelling of 'breast'

Posts.Content: Mark,         Since finishing chemo and just on Herceptin now all I have had is the drippy nose. It just comes at the most awkward moments and sometimes doesn't even give you time to grab a tissue. Thank goodness for sleeves, haha!  I do still feel very tired but put that down to hangover from chemo, extra surgery recently and radiotherapy ongoing now.
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: I have kept a diary from the beginning. Not too much detail but logs of chemo dates, side effects, temperatures, hospital stays, seroma draining dates and quantities. You do forget some of the crap we all go through and the chemo brain gets confused so it's useful to look back on and actually now think 'that was bad but I did it and I'm almost out the other end'
Posts.Title: Keep a diary

Posts.Content: Hi Amanda, Doxataxel is truly the work of the devil isn't it, I found that the FEC was tolerable although I was hospitalised every time with high temps but was able to get two fairly ok weeks out of three but with the dreaded T I was neutropenic every time and hospitalised every time again. By the third dose I didn't get any 'good' days at all, just constant bad stuff - aches, debilitating fatigue, mouth like a dead ferret had taken residence, constipation. I spent 32 nights in hospital overall. So that's all the bad stuff. The good news is that it's all temporary! 4 months post chemo and 2 months post radiotherapy I'm feeling pretty much ok and the bad stuff is just a memory. I got through it all and am here to tell the tale. You'll get through it too and whatever you have to put up with its getting rid of the cancer so worth a few months of shit!
Posts.Title: Docetaxel Side Effects

Posts.Content: London lass, your point about the photo made me laugh. I asked the question when they took my photo and said surely you wouldn't get anyone who wasn't the patient coming for radiotherapy and to my surprise she said that actually it had happened a few times. One guy was so frightened that his brother went in his place and it was only the fact that the particular radiotherapy he had needed a mould that has been made to fit the actual patient that they realised it was the brother!
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy planning appointment
